page.title: 01 GAZETTEER
page.content:
The area's population is predominantly English in its language. This has been the case since the 9th Century; to the West it is Welsh. Until 30 years ago Mynydd Isa belonged to the latter but the recent influx of English from Merseyside has resulted in Anglicization. Place names still reflect the bilingual nature of this stretch of borderland.
WELSH: Yr Wyddgrug, Mynydd Isa, Bryn-y-baal, Argoed, Prenbrigog, Llwynegrin, Llong, Bannel.
ENGLISH: Buckley, Bistre, Brury, Burntwood, Spon Green, Padeswood, New Brighton, Little Mountain.
Mold belongs to neither, it being Normans-French; originally Mont Alto 'high hill'.
